ground_truth: In contrast to those around him, there is tension in Godse's face, an air of danger in his movements. He glances at two policemen who are talking casually, absorbed in their own gossip, then looks back at another Tonga that pulls up just behind his. Two young men, Apte and Karkare, meet Godse's gaze, and again there is a sense of imminent danger. They descend and pay their driver absently, their eyes watching the crowd. Sitting alone in the shadows of a stationary Tonga a little distance down the street, an elderly man named Prakash with a short, close-cropped beard and the taut, sunken flesh of a cadaver is watching. Apte and Karkare look back at him. There is just the slightest acknowledgment, and then Prakash lifts his eyes to the gate, as though to tell them to be about their business. Godse hesitates before approaching the two gardeners who nonchalantly flank the entrance. He stiffens himself, cautiously touches something under his khaki jacket, then glances back at the stoic face of Prakash. Prakash's gaze is as firm and unrelenting as a death's head. Godse turns back, wetting his lips nervously, then moves into the middle of a group going through the gate. A fairly numerous crowd is gathering here, informally filling the area on one side of a walk that leads to a little pavilion -- some devout, some curious, some just eager to be near the great man. Apte and Karkare move to different sides of Godse, staying a little behind, their movements sly and wary, aware of people watching. He is seen distantly through the crowd. He is not seen clearly until the very last moment, only glimpses of him as he smiles and exchanges little jokes with some of the crowd and the two young women who support him, occasionally joining his hands together in greeting to someone in particular, then once more proceeding with a hand on the shoulder of each of the girls. The camera keeps moving closer, and the point of view is always Godse's, but Gandhi is always in profile or half obscured by the heads and shoulders of those in front. Godse slides through to the very front rank. His breathing is short, and there is perspiration around the sides of his temples. Now, for an instant, Gandhi is seen close from his point of view. He is only a few steps away, but turned to speak to someone on the other side, and Manu half obscures him. Godse swallows dryly, tension lining his face, then moves boldly out into Gandhi's path, bumping Manu and knocking a vessel for incense from her hands. Ignoring her, his nerves even more taut, Godse joins his hands together and bows in greeting to the Mahatma.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description:
Sure, here's the text with synonyms replacing the non-stop words:

In comparison to these around him, there exists strain in Godse's visage, an aura of peril in his actions. He peeks at a pair of officers who are chatting informally, engrossed in their own talk, then observes again at another carriage that draws up just behind his. Two youthful males, Apte and Karkare, meet Godse's look, and again there is an impression of impending peril. They alight and remunerate their driver inattentively, their gazes scanning the throng. Seated solitary in the shadows of a motionless carriage a slight distance down the road, an aged individual named Prakash with a brief, close-trimmed beard and the tight, sunken skin of a corpse is observing. Apte and Karkare glance back at him. There is merely the faintest acknowledgment, and then Prakash raises his eyes to the gate, as if to instruct them to proceed with their undertaking. Godse pauses before nearing the couple of gardeners who casually border the entry. He braces himself, cautiously taps something beneath his tan coat, then peeks back at the stoic countenance of Prakash. Prakash's stare is as resolute and unyielding as a skull. Godse turns back, moistening his lips apprehensively, then proceeds into the center of a gathering passing through the gate. A rather sizable throng is assembling here, informally occupying the space on one flank of a path that leads to a little pavilion -- some pious, some inquisitive, some just keen to be near the eminent individual. Apte and Karkare shift to opposite sides of Godse, remaining a little behind, their actions cunning and watchful, conscious of individuals observing. He is perceived distantly through the throng. He is not perceived distinctly until the very ultimate moment, only glimpses of him as he grins and trades small witticisms with some of the throng and the pair of youthful females who escort him, occasionally uniting his hands together in salutation to someone in particular, then once more advancing with a hand on the shoulder of each of the girls. The camera continues moving nearer, and the standpoint is always Godse's, but Gandhi is always in profile or partially obscured by the craniums and shoulders of those in front. Godse glides through to the very forefront rank. His respiration is brief, and there is sweat around the peripheries of his temples. Now, for a moment, Gandhi is perceived close from his viewpoint. He is only a few paces away, but turned to address someone on the other flank, and Manu partially obscures him. Godse swallows hoarsely, strain etching his visage, then proceeds courageously out into Gandhi's course, jostling Manu and dislodging a vessel for fragrance from her hands. Disregarding her, his nerves even more tight, Godse unites his hands together and inclines in salutation to the Mahatma.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: In contrast to those around him, tension is present in Godse's face, and danger is conveyed by his movements. Two policemen are glanced at by him, talking casually and absorbed in their own gossip, then his gaze returns to another Tonga that is pulled up just behind his. Godse's gaze is met by two young men, Apte and Karkare, and a sense of imminent danger is conveyed again. They descend and the driver is paid absently by them, their eyes watching the crowd. Sitting alone in the shadows of a stationary Tonga a little distance down the street, Prakash, an elderly man with a short, close-cropped beard and the taut, sunken flesh of a cadaver, watches. Apte and Karkare look back at him. Just the slightest acknowledgment is given, and then his eyes are lifted to the gate by Prakash, as though to tell them to be about their business. Before approaching the two gardeners who nonchalantly flank the entrance, Godse hesitates. Himself is stiffened, something is cautiously touched under his khaki jacket, then he glances back at Prakash's stoic face. Prakash's gaze remains firm and unrelenting as a death's head. Godse turns back, his lips being wetted nervously, then he moves into the middle of a group going through the gate. Here, a fairly numerous crowd gathers, informally filling the area on one side of a walk that leads to a little pavilion -- some being devout, some curious, some just eager to be near the great man. Different sides of Godse are moved to by Apte and Karkare, a little behind staying, their movements sly and wary, aware of people watching. He sees the crowd distantly through the crowd. Clearly, he is not seen until the very last moment, only glimpses of him are seen as he smiles and exchanges little jokes with some of the crowd and the two young women who support him, occasionally joining his hands together in greeting to someone in particular, then once more proceeding with a hand on the shoulder of each of the girls. The camera keeps moving closer, and Godse's point of view is always used, but Gandhi is always seen in profile or half obscured by the heads and shoulders of those in front. To the very front rank, Godse slides through. His breathing is short, and perspiration is around the sides of his temples. Now, from his point of view, Gandhi is seen close for an instant. Only a few steps away is he seen, but Gandhi turns to speak to someone on the other side, and Manu half obscures him. Godse swallows dryly, tension lining his face, then Gandhi's path is boldly moved into by him, Manu being bumped and a vessel for incense knocked from her hands. She is ignored by him, his nerves even more taut, he joins his hands together and bows in greeting to the Mahatma.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: In contrast to those nearby, tension marks Godse's face and his movements convey danger. He notices two policemen absorbed in gossip and looks at a Tonga arriving behind his. Apte and Karkare meet Godse’s gaze, exuding imminent danger. They exit and pay the driver absentmindedly, eyes on the crowd. An elderly man, Prakash, with a close-cropped beard and cadaverous appearance, watches from a stationary Tonga down the street. Apte and Karkare glance at him, acknowledging slightly, as Prakash lifts his eyes to the gate, urging them on. Godse hesitates at the entrance flanked by relaxed gardeners, touches something hidden under his khaki jacket, and glances at the stoic Prakash. Prakash's gaze is firm, like a death's head. Godse nervously wets his lips and joins a group entering the gate. A sizable crowd gathers, some devout, some curious, near the great man. Apte and Karkare stay a little behind Godse, wary of observers. Godse is seen indistinctly in the crowd, exchanging jokes and greetings, supported by two young women. The camera closes in from Godse's perspective, but Gandhi remains in profile or obscured. Godse moves to the front, breathing heavily, perspiration at his temples. Gandhi appears close from Godse's view, turned away to speak, half-obscured by Manu. Godse swallows nervously and boldly steps into Gandhi’s path, bumping Manu and causing her incense vessel to fall. Ignoring this, Godse, nerves taut, joins his hands in greeting to Gandhi.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: In contrast to others, tension marks Godse's face, danger in his movements. He eyes two gossiping policemen and glances at a Tonga behind him. Apte and Karkare meet his gaze, sensing danger. They pay their driver absentmindedly, eyes on the crowd. Prakash, an elderly man with a cadaverous look, watches alone from a distant Tonga. Apte and Karkare acknowledge him subtly. Prakash signals them to proceed by looking at the gate. Godse hesitates, touches something under his khaki jacket, and looks back at Prakash's relentless gaze. Nervously, he joins a group entering the gate, where a crowd gathers around a pavilion. Apte and Karkare remain wary behind Godse. He is glimpsed through the crowd, smiling, joking, and greeting with two young women supporting him. The camera always shows Gandhi in profile or obscured until Godse reaches the front. Breathing short, perspiring, Godse sees Gandhi close. As Gandhi turns to speak, Manu partially obscures him. Godse swallows, tension evident, and boldly steps into Gandhi's path, bumping Manu and knocking an incense vessel. Ignoring her, Godse bows in greeting to the Mahatma.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
In stark contrast to the individuals surrounding him, there is a palpable tension etched across Godse's face, accompanied by an unmistakable aura of danger in his every movement. He glances over at two policemen, who are engaged in a casual conversation, seemingly absorbed in their own gossip, then shifts his gaze back to observe another Tonga that has just pulled up immediately behind his own. Two young men, named Apte and Karkare, catch Godse's gaze, and once again there is a pervasive sense of impending danger. They descend from the Tonga and pay their driver with an absent-minded air, all while keeping their eyes vigilantly watching the gathering crowd.

Seated alone in the murky shadows of a stationary Tonga situated a little further down the street, there is an elderly man named Prakash. He has a short, close-cropped beard combined with the taut, sunken skin reminiscent of a cadaver and is intently watching the events unfold. Apte and Karkare glance back at him. There is just the slightest nod of acknowledgment, a subtle exchange, and then Prakash lifts his eyes towards the gate, as if to silently urge them to proceed with their task. Godse hesitates momentarily before moving towards the two gardeners who are casually flanking the entrance. He stiffens his posture, cautiously reaching to touch something hidden beneath his khaki jacket, then nervously glances back at the stoic face of Prakash. Prakash's unyielding gaze is as steady and implacable as a death's head.

Godse turns back, wetting his lips in a nervous gesture, and then steps into the midst of a group passing through the gate. A rather sizeable crowd is beginning to gather in this area, informally filling up the space on one side of a walkway that leads to a small pavilion -- some individuals are devout, others merely curious, and some are simply eager to be near the great man. Apte and Karkare position themselves on different sides of Godse, lingering slightly behind him. Their movements are sly and cautious, fully aware of the watchful eyes of the crowd. Godse is observed distantly through the throng. He does not come into clear view until the very last moment, with only occasional glimpses of him as he exchanges small jokes and smiles with some members of the crowd and the two young women who accompany him. Every now and then, he joins his hands together in greeting to someone in particular, then proceeds once more with a hand placed on the shoulder of each young woman.

The camera continues to move closer, and the perspective remains centered on Godse's viewpoint, but Gandhi remains visible only in profile or partly obscured by the heads and shoulders of those in front. Godse navigates his way through to the very front rank. His breathing becomes shallow, and perspiration is visible around the sides of his temples. At this moment, Gandhi can be seen from Godse's perspective, only a few steps away, but turned to engage someone on the opposite side, partially obscured by Manu. Godse swallows with a dry throat, tension visible on his face, then makes a bold move directly into Gandhi's path, bumping into Manu and inadvertently knocking a vessel for incense from her hands. Ignoring her reaction, his nerves now more taut than ever, Godse joins his hands together and bows in greeting to the Mahatma.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
In stark contrast to the individuals surrounding him in a bustling environment filled with varied personas, there exists a palpable tension etched across Godse's face, an undeniable sign of the inner turmoil boiling beneath the surface. This tension is accompanied by an unmistakable aura of danger, intricately woven into his every calculated movement. He casts a brief yet penetrating glance over at two policemen, who appear to be engaged in a casual and light-hearted conversation, seemingly absorbed in their own world of gossip and chatter, then shifts his intent gaze back to observe another Tonga that has just pulled up directly behind his own. In this new arrival, two young men, bearing the names Apte and Karkare, catch Godse's focused gaze, and once again, there is a pervasive sense of impending danger that seems to linger in the air. The two men descend gracefully from the Tonga and pay their driver, their demeanor absent-minded and preoccupied, all while keeping their vigilant eyes meticulously watching the gathering crowd around them.

Seated alone in the murky, obscured shadows of a stationary Tonga positioned a bit further down the bustling street, there is an elderly man known as Prakash. His appearance is striking, with a short and neatly close-cropped beard, combined with taut, sunken skin that eerily reminds one of a cadaver. He is intently watching the unfolding events with a focused intensity. Apte and Karkare, catching his eye, glance back at him. There is just the slightest, almost imperceptible nod of acknowledgment, a subtle and wordless exchange between them, and then Prakash lifts his eyes toward the gate, as if to silently urge them to proceed with their task, with a silent command not needing words. Godse hesitates momentarily, a brief pause in his step before he begins moving toward the two gardeners who are casually flanking the entrance. He stiffens his posture, cautiously reaching to touch something hidden beneath his khaki jacket, then nervously casts a glance back at the stoic face of Prakash. Prakash's unyielding gaze remains as steady and implacable as a death's head, giving an eerie sense of inevitability.

Godse turns back, wetting his lips in a nervous gesture filled with tension, then boldly steps into the midst of a group passing through the gate. A sizeable crowd is beginning to gather in this area, informally filling up the space on one side of a walkway that leads to a small pavilion—some individuals are devout, others merely curious, and some simply eager for a chance to be near the great man they admire. Apte and Karkare astutely position themselves on different sides of Godse, lingering slightly behind him with deliberate intent. Their movements are sly and cautious, fully aware of the many watchful eyes fixated on them from the crowd. Godse is observed from a distance through the throng of people. He does not come into clear view until the very last moment, with only occasional, fleeting glimpses of him as he exchanges small jokes and smiles, engaging with some members of the crowd and the two young women who accompany him. Every now and then, he joins his hands together in a traditional greeting to someone in particular, then proceeds once more with a hand placed reassuringly on the shoulder of each young woman.

The camera continues to move closer, focusing on Godse's viewpoint, but Gandhi remains visible only in profile or partly obscured by the heads and shoulders of those standing in front. Godse navigates his way through to the very front rank, his breathing becoming shallow in anticipation, and visible perspiration forms around the sides of his temples. At this critical moment, Gandhi can be seen from Godse's perspective, only a few short steps away, yet turned to engage someone on the opposite side, partially obscured by Manu. Godse swallows with a dry throat, the tension evident on his face as it draws taut, then makes a bold and decisive move directly into Gandhi's path. In doing so, he inadvertently bumps into Manu, causing her to drop a vessel meant for incense from her hands. Ignoring her reaction completely, his nerves now more taut than ever before, Godse joins his hands together and bows in respectful greeting to the Mahatma.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: In contrast to those around him, there is a palpable tension etched on Godse's face, each of his movements carrying an air of danger that sets him apart from the crowd. He swiftly glances at two policemen who are standing nearby, engaged in casual conversation and deeply absorbed in their own gossip, seemingly unaware of the surroundings. Godse's eyes then shift back to another Tonga that has just pulled up directly behind his own. In this moment, two young men, Apte and Karkare, catch Godse's gaze, and this silent exchange enhances the sense of imminent danger. With a deliberate motion, they descend from the Tonga and absentmindedly hand payment to their driver as their eyes continuously scan the bustling crowd. Meanwhile, an elderly man named Prakash, with a short, close-cropped beard and taut, sunken flesh reminiscent of a cadaver, sits cloaked in the shadows of a stationary Tonga a little farther down the street, his eyes fixed on the unfolding scene. Apte and Karkare briefly turn their attention back to him, exchanging the slightest of acknowledgments before Prakash subtly lifts his gaze towards the gate, silently urging them to proceed with their task. Godse hesitates momentarily as he approaches the two gardeners lounging nonchalantly by the entrance. He braces himself, cautiously touches something concealed beneath his khaki jacket, and glances back at Prakash's stoic expression, which remains as unyielding as a death's head. Returning his focus forward, Godse nervously wets his lips and maneuvers into the midst of a group making their way through the gate. A fairly sizable crowd is assembling there, informally occupying one side of the walkway that leads to a small pavilion—some members of the crowd are devout, others curious, and many simply eager to be near the great man. Apte and Karkare discreetly position themselves on either side of Godse, maintaining a slight distance, their movements calculated and wary, fully conscious of being observed. From a distance, Godse appears as just another figure in the crowd, his presence not entirely registered until the final moment. He is only partially visible, occasionally seen smiling and exchanging light-hearted jokes with some in the crowd and with two young women who support him, joining his hands in greeting to certain individuals, and then continuing with a supportive grip on each of the girls' shoulders. The camera draws ever closer, presenting the scene from Godse's perspective while Gandhi remains mostly in profile or partially obscured by the heads and shoulders of those in front. Godse maneuvers his way to the very front rank, his breathing becoming shallow and perspiration forming at his temples. For a fleeting instant, Gandhi is clearly visible from Godse's vantage point, only a few steps away, but he is engaged in conversation with someone opposite, and Manu partially blocks the view. Godse swallows with a dry throat, his face lined with tension, before boldly stepping into Gandhi's path, knocking into Manu and causing her to drop a vessel for incense. Disregarding the incident, his nerves now strained to the utmost, Godse clasps his hands together and bows in greeting to the Mahatma.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description:
In contrast to those around him, there is tension in Godse's face and an air of danger in his movements as he assesses his surroundings. He exchanges glances with two policemen engrossed in gossip, and then with Apte and Karkare, who have just arrived in a Tonga behind him. Apte and Karkare pay their driver distractedly while scanning the crowd. Nearby, Prakash, an elderly man with a cadaverous appearance, observes from the shadows of a stationary Tonga. A subtle acknowledgment passes between Apte, Karkare, and Prakash, who then directs his attention to the gate, signaling them to proceed. Godse hesitates before approaching the entrance, stiffens himself, and furtively checks beneath his khaki jacket. He glances back to meet Prakash's unyielding stare, then nervously licks his lips and merges into a group entering the gate. 

The area is bustling with a diverse crowd—some devout, some curious, and some eager to be near the great man. Apte and Karkare discreetly position themselves flanking Godse, maintaining a watchful distance as they navigate through the gathering. Godse blends into the crowd, observed only in passing as he exchanges smiles and jokes and occasionally greets individuals with joined hands. The camera moves closer, offering Godse's perspective, though Gandhi remains partially obscured by the crowd. Godse edges forward, breathing shallowly, perspiration dotting his temples, until Gandhi is momentarily seen up close, engaged in conversation and partly hidden by Manu. Godse swallows, his tension palpable, and steps assertively into Gandhi's path, brushing past Manu and causing her to drop an incense vessel. Ignoring the commotion, he steadies his heightened nerves, bows, and greets the Mahatma with joined hands.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: In contrast to those around him at the Birla House in New Delhi, where Gandhi was living, there is tension in Godse's face, an air of danger in his movements. He glances at two policemen who are talking casually, absorbed in their own gossip, seemingly oblivious to the larger events unfolding, then looks back at another Tonga, a horse-drawn carriage common in India at the time, that pulls up just behind his. Two young men, Apte, a known accomplice in Godse’s activities, and Karkare, who had ties with right-wing nationalist groups, meet Godse's gaze, and again there is a sense of imminent danger. They descend and pay their driver absently, their eyes scanning the crowd for potential threats or witnesses. Sitting alone in the shadows of a stationary Tonga a little distance down the street, an elderly man named Prakash with a short, close-cropped beard and the taut, sunken flesh of a cadaver is watching. Apte and Karkare look back at him; Prakash, whose real name was believed to be a pseudonym used within the group, was a figure of authority among them. There is just the slightest acknowledgment, and then Prakash lifts his eyes to the gate, the entrance to the prayer meeting, as though to tell them to be about their business. Godse hesitates before approaching the two gardeners who nonchalantly flank the entrance, their presence seemingly benign but important in the event's setting. He stiffens himself, cautiously touches something under his khaki jacket where he conceals a revolver, then glances back at the stoic face of Prakash. Prakash's gaze is as firm and unrelenting as a death's head, symbolizing the grave purpose behind their actions. Godse turns back, wetting his lips nervously, then moves into the middle of a group going through the gate toward Gandhi's prayer meeting. A fairly numerous crowd is gathering here, informally filling the area on one side of a walk that leads to a little pavilion where Gandhi often held his evening prayers -- some devout, some curious, some just eager to be near the great man, Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, affectionately known as the Father of the Nation. Apte and Karkare move to different sides of Godse, staying a little behind, their movements sly and wary, aware of people watching them in the tense atmosphere. He is seen distantly through the crowd. He is not seen clearly until the very last moment, only glimpses of him as he smiles and exchanges little jokes with some of the crowd and the two young women, Abha and Manu, who support him, occasionally joining his hands together in greeting to someone in particular, then once more proceeding with a hand on the shoulder of each of the girls. The camera keeps moving closer, and the point of view is always Godse's, but Gandhi, who had inspired millions with his philosophy of nonviolence, is always in profile or half obscured by the heads and shoulders of those in front. Godse slides through to the very front rank. His breathing is short, and there is perspiration around the sides of his temples. Now, for an instant, Gandhi is seen close from his point of view. He is only a few steps away, but turned to speak to someone on the other side, and Manu, Gandhi's grand-niece who attended him closely, half obscures him. Godse swallows dryly, tension lining his face, then moves boldly out into Gandhi's path, bumping Manu and knocking a vessel for incense from her hands. Ignoring her, his nerves even more taut, Godse joins his hands together and bows in greeting to the Mahatma, a traditional gesture of respect masking his sinister intentions.

Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. A fairly numerous crowd is gathering here informally filling the area on one side of a walk that leads to a little pavilion  some devout some curious some just eager to be near the great man. Apte and Karkare move to different sides of Godse staying a little behind their movements sly and wary aware of people watching. He is seen distantly through the crowd. He is not seen clearly until the very last moment only glimpses of him as he smiles and exchanges little jokes with some of the crowd and the two young women who support him occasionally joining his hands together in greeting to someone in particular then once more proceeding with a hand on the shoulder of each of the girls. The camera keeps moving closer and the point of view is always Godse's but Gandhi is always in profile or half obscured by the heads and shoulders of those in front. Godse slides through to the very front rank. His breathing is short and there is perspiration around the sides of his temples. Now for an instant Gandhi is seen close from his point of view. He is only a few steps away but turned to speak to someone on the other side and Manu half obscures him. Godse swallows dryly tension lining his face then moves boldly out into Gandhi's path bumping Manu and knocking a vessel for incense from her hands. Ignoring her his nerves even more taut. Godse joins his hands together and bows in greeting to the Mahatma.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: In contrast to those around him there is tension in Godse's face. an air of danger in his movements. He glances at two policemen who are talking casually absorbed in their own gossip then looks back at another Tonga that pulls up just behind his. Two young men Apte and Karkare meet Godse's gaze and again there is a sense of imminent danger. They descend and pay their driver absently their eyes watching the crowd. Sitting alone in the shadows of a stationary Tonga a little distance down the street an elderly man named Prakash with a short closecropped beard and the taut sunken flesh of a cadaver is watching. His breathing is short and there is perspiration around the sides of his temples. Now for an instant Gandhi is seen close from his point of view. He is only a few steps away but turned to speak to someone on the other side and Manu half obscures him. Godse swallows dryly tension lining his face then moves boldly out into Gandhi's path bumping Manu and knocking a vessel for incense from her hands. Ignoring her his nerves even more taut. Godse joins his hands together and bows in greeting to the Mahatma.

test_cases.description: In contrast to those around him there is tension in Godse's face. an air of danger in his movements. He glances at two policemen who are talking casually absorbed in their own gossip then looks back at another Tonga that pulls up just behind his. Ignoring her his nerves even more taut. Godse joins his hands together and bows in greeting to the Mahatma.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: In contrast to those around her, there is serenity in Lila's expression, an aura of calm in her gestures. She peers at two firemen who are dancing wildly, absorbed in their own festivities, then glances back at another wagon that glides up just behind hers. Two elderly women, Mira and Sonia, meet Lila's glance, and again there is a sense of impending celebration. They ascend and tip their chef absentmindedly, their eyes admiring the parade. Sitting quietly in the brightness of a moving cart a little distance down the street, a young girl named Tara with a long, flowing mane and the smooth, radiant skin of a cherub is observing. Mira and Sonia glance back at her. There is just the slightest wave, and then Tara lowers her head to the ground, as though to whisper for them to start their adventure. Lila pauses before approaching the two florists who carefully guard the entrance. She relaxes herself, cautiously strokes something inside her velvet cloak, then peers back at the joyful face of Tara. Tara's glance is as soft and inviting as a sunflower's bloom. Lila turns back, moistening her lips eagerly, then dances into the heart of a group passing through the archway. A fairly cheerful assembly is gathering here, casually filling the space on one side of a path that leads to a grand gazebo -- some delighted, some intrigued, some just eager to be near the kind figure. Mira and Sonia move to opposite sides of Lila, staying a little behind, their movements playful and lighthearted, aware of children playing. She is glimpsed distantly through the convocation. She is not seen clearly until the very last moment, only flashes of her as she laughs and and shares little stories with some of the assembly and the two young men who escort her, occasionally clasping her hands together in salutation to someone in particular, then once more striding with a hand on the arm of each of the boys. The lens keeps moving closer, and the perspective is always Lila's, but Raj is always in silhouette or partly veiled by the bodies and limbs of those in front. Lila dances through to the very front row. Her breath is full, and there is dew around the edges of her cheeks. Now, for a fleeting moment, Raj is seen closely from her viewpoint. He is only a few steps away, but turned to converse with someone on the opposite side, and Neha partly shields him. Lila swallows calmly, joy brightening her face, then steps gracefully into Raj's path, nudging Neha and knocking a bouquet of flowers from her grasp. Overlooking her, her excitement ever more vibrant, Lila clasps her hands together and waves in salute to the Guru.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Tension defines Godse, who frequently glances at two nearby policemen and a newly arrived Tonga with Apte and Karkare inside, indicating imminent danger. An elderly man, Prakash, observes from the shadows, subtly instructing them to proceed. Godse hesitates at the entrance, checking something beneath his jacket, then joins a group approaching a pavilion, where a crowd has gathered to see Gandhi. Apte and Karkare flank Godse, wary of attention. Godse navigates closer to Gandhi, who remains partially obscured by the crowd. As Godse reaches the front, he is perspiring and tense. Finally, he steps into Gandhi's path, bumping Manu and knocking an incense vessel from her hands, before greeting Gandhi with joined hands.
